title: Epigenetic clock indicates accelerated aging in glial cells of progressive multiple sclerosis patients

background: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic inflammatory neurodegenerative disease, and evidence suggests disease progression depends on age and inflammation within the CNS.
hypotheses: Epigenetic aging is accelerated in the brain tissue of progressive MS patients compared to controls.
Glial cells in progressive MS patients exhibit accelerated biological aging compared to controls.
major_findings: Glial cells from progressive MS patients showed a significant 3.6-year increase in age acceleration residuals compared to controls using the Cortical clock, even after adjusting for covariates.
No significant difference in age acceleration was observed in bulk brain tissue or neurons between MS patients and controls after adjusting for covariates.
null_findings: The 4.8-year age acceleration found in MS neurons did not remain significant after adjusting for covariates.
No significant difference in age acceleration residuals was observed in bulk brain tissue between MS patients and controls.
new_open_questions: What are the specific mechanisms driving accelerated aging in glial cells of progressive MS patients?
Do sex differences in epigenetic aging contribute to the clinical course of MS?
How do the findings translate to other neurological diseases?
methods: DNA methylation analysis using Illumina 450K and EPIC arrays
Epigenetic clock analysis using Horvath's clock and the Cortical clock
Statistical analysis including linear models, MANCOVA, and Tukey HSD test
